msgSnippet: ... Maybe. What do people think? For me, @BeforeClass and @AfterClass already mean before everything coming from _this_ class , and after everything coming

Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> On 8/11/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> There are indeed several ways to achieve this with JUnit, but why not simply
> add @BeforeSuite and @AfterSuite?  The intent would be much clearer,
> wouldn't it?
>   

Maybe. What do people think? For me, @BeforeClass and @AfterClass 
already mean "before everything coming from _this_ class", and "after 
everything coming from _this_ class", whether that's all the methods on 
a test class, or all the classes referenced from a Suite class. This 
means that @BeforeClass has a consistent meaning on both suite classes 
and test classes. If suite classes have BeforeSuite, and test classes 
have BeforeClass, then what does BeforeClass mean on a suite class? What 
does BeforeSuite mean on a test class? It seems that fewer concepts is 
better.

Thoughts from frequent JUnit users?

David
